bestBHT.bht: Finding their former ship unable to proceed any farther, Paul and his companions quickly boarded a new vessel set for Phoenicia. The level of detail provided gives a sense of the authenticity of the account, almost as if it were taken from a voyage journal. Despite still being four hundred miles away from Jerusalem, Paul fortunately found a merchantman in Patara that could sail directly across the open sea. Without delay, they boarded the ship and set forth on their journey to Phoenicia.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: And finding a ship—their former one going no farther, probably.
One would almost think this extracted from a journal of the voyage, so graphic are its details.
Albert Barnes: Unto Phenicia - See the notes on Acts 11:19. Phoenicia was on their way to Jerusalem.
Marvin Vincent: Set forth [ανηχθημεν] . Or set sail. See on Luke 8:22; Luke 5:3.
Philip Schaff: Patara was evidently the harbour whither his ship was bound from Alexandria Troas.
Thus not a day was lost.
Archibald T. Robertson: He was still some four hundred miles from Jerusalem."
But at Patara Paul caught a large vessel (a merchantman) that could sail across the open sea."
John Gill: Finding a ship sailing over unto Phoenicia.
Lighting on another ship, which was bound for Phoenicia, for the city of Tyre.
We went aboard; the said ship: and set forth; on the voyage.

bhtAttempts.bht: Finding their former ship unable to go any farther, Paul and his companions embarked on a new vessel to Phoenicia. The details provided in this passage give a sense of immediacy and authenticity to the account. It is worth noting that Paul was still quite a distance away from Jerusalem, about four hundred miles. Nonetheless, at Patara, Paul managed to find a large ship capable of sailing across the open sea. Without any delay, they boarded the vessel and set sail towards Phoenicia.

Discovering that their previous ship could not proceed any further, Paul and his companions embarked on a new vessel bound for Phoenicia. The level of vivid detail in the account is so precise that it resembles a journal entry. Despite still being a considerable distance away from Jerusalem, approximately four hundred miles, Paul seized the fortuitous circumstance of finding a merchantman in Patara that could sail directly across the open sea. Without wasting any time, they immediately boarded the ship and commenced their voyage to Phoenicia.

Finding their former ship unable to proceed any farther, Paul and his companions quickly boarded a new vessel set for Phoenicia. The level of detail provided gives a sense of the authenticity of the account, almost as if it were taken from a voyage journal. Despite still being four hundred miles away from Jerusalem, Paul fortunately found a merchantman in Patara that could sail directly across the open sea. Without delay, they boarded the ship and set forth on their journey to Phoenicia.

Upon realizing that their previous ship could not continue their journey, Paul and his companions wasted no time in boarding a new vessel bound for Phoenicia. The level of detail provided in this account is striking, almost resembling entries from a voyage journal. Though still hundreds of miles away from Jerusalem, Paul's circumstances allowed him to find a suitable merchant ship in Patara that could sail across the open sea. Capitalizing on the opportunity, they promptly boarded the ship and embarked on their voyage to Phoenicia.

After discovering that their former ship could proceed no further, Paul and his companions swiftly boarded a new vessel bound for Phoenicia. The meticulous details presented in the account lend an air of authenticity to the narrative, almost resembling excerpts from a voyage journal. Despite still being approximately four hundred miles away from Jerusalem, Paul fortuitously found a sizable merchant ship in Patara that was capable of sailing across the open sea. Without hesitation, they promptly embarked on the ship, commencing their voyage towards Phoenicia.
